questions.text: A 60 years old male patient believes that his thoughts and feelings are controlled by some external agency. This is? (FMGE recent)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Delusion of influence

Nihilistic delusions or delusions of negation occur when the patient denies the existence of their body, their mind, their loved ones and the world around them.

Delusions of influence are a ‘logical’ result of experiences of passivity in the context of schizophrenia. These passivity feelings may be explained by the patient as the result of hypnotism, demonical possession, witchcraft, radio waves, atomic rays or television. (Fish’s)

questions.text: Tactile hallucinations seen with use of cocaine are known as: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Formication (Definition)

questions.text: La belle indifference is a disturbance of: (***)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Affect (Ref : Page 68 Fish’s clinical psychopathology)

“Another variant of dissociation of affect is the belle indifférence that is seen in conversion disorder.”

It is lack of emotional reactivity to sufferings.

questions.text: A young man gets sudden and irresistible urge to carry out an act.  Which of the following is an impulse control disorder? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sudden irresistible urge to carry out an act is impulse

Intermittent explosive disorder is an impulse control disorder

questions.text: On Mental status examination, patient is asked to subtract 7 from 100. What does it assess? (FMGE)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Although serial 100-7 subtraction test is for both attention and concentration

But concentration is a better answer here than attention

questions.text: SCOFF criterion questionnaire are used in evaluation for? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Eating Disorders
The SCOFF* questionnaire (Screening for eating disorders)
S:  Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
C : Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
O : Have you recently lost more than One stone in a 3-month period?
F : Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are thin?
F : Would you say that Food dominates your life?

questions.text: Russel’s sign is usually associated with which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bulimia Nervosa

Russel’s sign:
It refers to skin abrasions, on the dorsum of fingers.
These occur due to repeated contact between the incisors and the skin of the hand which occurs during self-induced vomiting.

questions.text: Clinical history is suggestive of premature ejaculation in male, with history of relationship conflicts with wife. Non pharmacological treatment for the couple used in this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Squeeze therapy

In cases of premature ejaculation, an exercise known as the squeeze technique is used to raise the threshold of penile excitability. In that exercise, the man or the woman stimulates the erect penis until the earliest sensations of impending orgasm and ejaculation are felt. Penile stimulation is then stopped abruptly, and the coronal ridge of the penis is squeezed forcibly for several seconds. The technique is repeated several times.
During those exercises, called sensate focus exercises, the couple is given much reinforcement to lessen anxiety. They are urged to use fantasies to distract them from obsessive concerns about performance, which is termed spectatoring.

questions.text: A 35 year old man with an Anankastic personality disorder is likely to exhibit all of following features, except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Compulsive Checking behaviour (Ref : Kaplan synopsis 11th edition, pg 756)

Compulsive checking behaviour is seen in OCD, and not in OCPD (Anankastic)

Persons with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder are preoccupied with rules, regulations, orderliness, neatness, details, and the achievement of perfection. These traits account for the general constriction of the entire personality. They insist that rules be followed rigidly and cannot tolerate what they consider infractions. 

Accordingly, they lack flexibility and are intolerant. They are capable of prolonged work, provided it is routinized and does not require changes to which they cannot adapt. Persons with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder have limited interpersonal skills. They are formal and serious and often lack a sense of humor. 

They alienate persons, are unable to compromise, and insist that others submit to their needs. They are eager to please those whom they see as more powerful than they are, however, and they carry out these persons' wishes in an authoritarian manner. Because they fear making mistakes, they are indecisive and ruminate about making decisions. 

Although a stable marriage and occupational adequacy are common, persons with obsessive-compulsive personality disorder have few friends. 
Anything that threatens to upset their perceived stability or the routine of their lives can precipitate much anxiety otherwise bound up in the rituals that they impose on their lives and try to impose on others.

choices.text: Hypnagogic hallucinations are more specific than hypnapompic hallucinations
Cataplexy is not a pathognomonic sign
Day time sleep attacks is most common symptom
SOREM (Sleep onset rem) is seen on sleep studies

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about “narcolepsy”? (**)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cataplexy is not a pathognomonic sign
Narcolepsy is a condition characterized by the brain’s inability to control sleepwake cycle. The narcoleptic tetrad:
• Sleep attacks and excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS)
• Cataplexy (pathognomonic sign)
• Hypnagogic hallucinations (hypnopompic can occur, but not pathognomonic): hypnagogic is while falling asleep and hypnopompic is while waking up
• Sleep paralysis
Narcolepsy is a disorder of REM sleep: onset of REM within 10 minutes. Linked to deficiency in hypocretin when cataplexy is present. Loss of hypocretin results in an inability to regulate sleep.

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with complaint that aliens are communicating with him they are sending an electromagnetic radiation to his brain and aliens are asking him to kill his distant relatives. His relative said he has this disease from last 20 years, The patient does not work on farm and stopped going in social functions, patient is aware of time, place and person. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Schizophrenia

“that aliens are communicating with him they are sending an electromagnetic radiation to his brain and aliens are asking him to kill his distant relatives” (Auditory hallucinations commanding the patient : first rank symptom)
Duration more than 6 months (20 years chronic continuous)
Social impairment

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with complains of irritability, hearing voices, suspiciousness since 4 days following an episode of fever. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brief Psychotic Disorder
BRIEF PSYCHOTIC DISORDER:
Symptoms similar to Schizophrenia
Onset- Acute
Often preceded by a stressor
Often resolves completely
Duration- <1 month
Rx- Antipsychotics
Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition

questions.text: A 46-year-old female came to the OPD with her husband, with complains that she is hearing multiple voices in her ears, commenting on her actions with derogatory manner, suspicious that her neighbours are trying to hurt her and that she is being tracked by them since 3 years. She also complains that she is not getting adequate sleep since then. Her husband reports that she hardly interacts with him. She does not interact with any one much. No precipitating factor could be elicited. Which of the following is not a poor prognostic factor in the case described?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Presence of positive symptoms

The clinical picture described in the above question is suggestive of Schizophrenia. Presence of psychotic symptoms such as auditory hallucinations and delusion of persecution, female sex and late age of onset goes in favour of good prognosis, where as the absence of precipitating factor, reduced interaction, and duration of illness goes in favour of poor prognosis

questions.text: The brain pathway most closely associated with the display of positive symptoms in schizophrenia is the:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mesolimbic tract

Increase dopamine in mesolimbic pathway is responsible for positive symptoms

Decrease dopamine in mesocortical pathway is responsible for negative symptoms

choices.text: Minimum duration needed to diagnose is 1 year

questions.text: All are true about simple schizophrenia except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Delusions and hallucinations

Positive symptoms are not commonly seen in simple schizophrenia. Social withdrawal and negative symptoms are usually prominent.

questions.text: All are features of catatonia except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

cataplexy
Very confusing at times!!!
Cataplexy – loss of tone- seen in narcolepsy
Catalepsy – increased tone-seen in catatonia

questions.text: All of the following are true about "Late onset schizophrenia" except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Onset after 40 y of age

Cut off is onset after 45 y of age to call as late onset schizophrenia

questions.text: What is the term used to describe increased sexual desire in males? (NEET)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased sexual desire in males is known as satyriasis

Increased sexual desire in females is known as nymphomaniac

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Cluster C: Obsessive compulsive personality disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: What is the key common symptom of depression? (FMGE)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Low mood
(Ref : Kaplan Psychiatry Pg 365)
Low mood is key symptom of depression.
Generalized psychomotor retardation is the most common symptom of depression, although psychomotor agitation is also seen, especially in older patients

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician complaining that he is “just not feeling like myself.” This feeling began soon after his younger brother passed away from cancer 3 months ago. The patient is no longer interested in work or going out with friends on weekends. He falls asleep relatively easily at night but awakes very early in the morning and is unable to fall back asleep. He admits to feeling “down in the dumps,” especially when he first wakes up but says that  his mood improves a little during the day. The patient often thinks  about ways that he could have spent more time with his brother. He feels guilty about his brother’s death being his fault “because I am worthless and could not love him enough.” His poor energy and concentration have started to affect his performance at work, and he frequently thinks that he should just quit “because I am bringing everyone down.” The patient has been eating less and has lost 3 kgs over the past few weeks. What is this patient’s most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Symptoms

meet the diagnostic criteria of major depressive disorder in this given scenario.

This patient meets diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode (depressed mood, loss of interest, early-morning awakening, weight loss, low energy, impaired concentration, feelings of worthlessness, and excessive guilt lasting at least 2 weeks). He has no prior psychiatric history and so would be diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Although his symptoms developed in response to a stressor, they meet full criteria for a major depressive episode, thereby ruling out adjustment disorder and grief reaction.
The death of a loved one is similar to any other serious stressor that can trigger a major depressive episode. 
(Choice A) Adjustment disorders are characterized by increased anxiety, depression, or disturbed behaviour that develops in response to a stressor. Symptoms must develop within 3 months of an identifiable stressor and last no more than 6 months after the stressor ends. In adjustment disorder with depressed mood, the full criteria for a major depressive episode are not met. By convention, if the patient's symptoms meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode, the diagnosis of an adjustment disorder is not applicable.
Not bereavement because symptoms are present for more than 2 months
(Choice D) Although this patient is grieving, his depression symptoms are more persistent and severe than those seen in a typical grief reaction. The dominant feelings in grief are loss and emptiness; in a major depressive episode, anhedonia and persistent epressed mood predominate. The sadness involved in grief will likely decrease in intensity over a period of weeks, with intermittent increases or "waves" following reminders of the deceased. In contrast, the sadness involved in a major depressive episode is more persistent and less specific. In grief, patients experience memories and thoughts of the deceased. A major depressive episode involves more negative and self-critical ruminations, with feelings of worthlessness and self -loathing.

choices.text: Should definitely have an episode of severe depression
Should definitely have an episode of mania
Should have major periods of hypomania

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about “cyclothymia”? (NIMHANS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

minimum duration to diagnose is 2yrs (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

If symptoms consist of persistent instability of mood between mild depression and mild elation, the disorder is called as cyclothymia. These disorders are characterised by persistent mood symptoms which last for more than 2 years (1 year in children and adolescents) but are not severe enough to be labelled as even hypomanic or mild depressive episode.

questions.text: Which of the following features seen in a 12 y old child suffering from depression is not suggestive of development of bipolar disorder later? (JIPMER)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came to the OPD with complains of sadness of mood, anhedonia, disturbed sleep and appetite since 3 years. She reports that she is not able to remember the time when she was happy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neurotic depression or Dysthymia
 
Dysthymia:
It is the presence of depressive symptoms that are less severe than that of major depressive disorder.
But it persists for more than 2 years.
Previously k/a neurotic depression.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy was brought to ER with complains of irritability and reduced sleep since 4 days. On examination, patient was found to be talking continuously and he could not be stopped, saying that he knew the PM & President of the country. Following assessment, he was admitted in a psychiatric facility. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mania
 

Although the patient had the symptoms for only 4 days (duration criteria for mania is 7 days), the symptoms are severe enough for admission.
If there are severe symptoms which warrant admission, then it is diagnosed as mania.

choices.text: Suicide after taking low dose of drug
Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

questions.text: Paradoxical suicide is seen in: (AIIMS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

Patients with depressive disorders are at increased risk of suicide as they begin to improve and regain the energy needed to plan and carry out a suicide (paradoxical suicide).  (Ref : Kaplan)

questions.text: Patient has had manic and depressive episodes and needs treatment. Which of the following causes least weight gain? (FMGE JAN 2024 )
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ziprasidone (reference : Maudsley clinical guidelines 13th )

Ziprasidone causes least weight gain

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants is most selectively serotonergic? (**)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Escitalopram  

Escitalopram is the most selective inhibitor of serotonin reuptake, with negligible effects on the reuptake of other monoamines such as norepinephrine or dopamine. It does not have any clinically significant effect on histaminergic, GABAergic, or acetylcholinergic transmission. Paroxetine has clinically significant anticholinergic activity. Fluoxetine weakly inhibits norepinephrine reuptake and binds to 5-HT2C receptors. Sertraline weakly inhibits both norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake

questions.text: All the following drugs are used in long term prophylaxis of recurrent depression except (NIMHANS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sodium valproate is not used in depression prophylaxis.

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Can be seen in seizure and migraine patients
More common in females then males

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding depersonalization? (AIIMS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reality contact is lost

DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria for Depersonalization Disorder
Persistent or recurrent experiences of feeling detached from, and as if one is an outside observer of, one's mental processes or body (e.g., feeling like one is in a dream). 
During the depersonalization experience, reality testing remains intact. 
The depersonalization causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning. 
The depersonalization experience does not occur exclusively during the course of another mental disorder, such as schizophrenia, panic disorder, acute stress disorder, or another dissociative disorder, and is not due to the direct physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or a general medical condition (e.g., temporal lobe epilepsy).

questions.text: Which one of the following specific phobias is strongly genetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blood injury injection phobia (Ref : Kaplan)

Blood injury injection phobia is different from other phobias in two important aspects: (1) the autonomic response to exposure is low blood pressure, bradycardia, and fainting response instead of the more common tachycardia, increased blood pressure, and flight response;
and (2) there is a strong genetic component in the aetiology of blood injury injection type of phobia. The affected persons may have inherited a particularly strong vasovagal reflex, which becomes associated with phobic emotions.

questions.text: A  patient presented in emergency with chest pain and no medical cause was found and patient told 10 days ago he was robbed on gun point in his house. When doctor wanted to discharge him he refused to go back to his home. His family member told his pre morbid condition before this incident was normal. Likely diagnosis? FMGE JAN 2024
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute onset anxiety symptoms with avoidance, 10 days after a major trauma with avoidance (refuses to go home), points towards diagnosis of acute stress reaction.

questions.text: Which of the following defense mechanisms is not involved in psychodynamics of OCD? (JIPMER)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation
Defense mechanisms involved in OCD are
1. Undoing
2. Reaction formation
3. Displacement
4. Isolation of affect
5. Repression
6. Regression

questions.text: A 27 -year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of abdominal pain for the past 2 years. The pain is constant and unrelated to meals. She also complains of nausea and a bloating sensation. The patient has had no weight or bowel movement changes. She has consulted many physicians about her problem and has undergone multiple endoscopies and colonoscopies and  an exploratory laparoscopy to no avail. She has been unable to work as she cannot focus on anything other than her physical discomfort. The patient is very frustrated that physicians have been unable to arrive at a diagnosis  and pleads for help. Her father died of colon cancer 5 years ago at 65. Physical examination shows no abnormalities, and an extensive laboratory workup is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Somatic symptom disorder

This patient's history and presentation are consistent with somatic symptom disorder.
 According to the DSM- 5, patients have somatic symptom disorder if they have:
• One or more physical symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life
• Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to these symptoms
• Persistent symptoms for 6 months
These symptoms may represent normal bodily sensations or minor discomfort that does not signify serious disease. They may or may not be associated with another medical condition, and concurrent medical illness is not mutually exclusive. If another medical condition or high risk for developing one is present (eg, family history), the preoccupation with any new symptoms is typically excessive. These individuals often use medical services frequently.

choices.text: Generalized anxiety disorder with panic attacks

questions.text: A 43-years-old man comes to the physician with a 3-months history of nervousness and excitability. He states that he feels this way constantly and that this is a dramatic change for his normally relaxed personality. He notes that on occasion he becomes extremely afraid of his own impending death, even when there is no objective evidence that this would occur. He notes that he has lost 3 kgs and frequently has diarrhea. On mental status examination, he is noted to have pressured speech. On physical examination, he is noted to have a fine tremor and tachycardia. Which of the following disorders is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hyperthyroidism
Presence of anxiety symptoms, weight loss, diarrhoea, tachycardia and tremors point towards the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism which is itself one of the commonest organic cause of anxiety disorder.
 

PARTS OF A PSYCHIATRIC DIAGNOSIS

A. SYMPTOMS
B. DURATION
C. DYSFUNCTION
D. MUST NOT BE EXPLAINABLE BY SUBSTANCE
E. MUST NOT BE EXPLAINABLE BY MEDICAL CAUSE

questions.text: A 14 year girl came to OPD with complaints of sudden onset blindness since 2 hours. On examination, she is not much concerned about this blindness. Physical examination is normal. During history taking she was only found upset while talking about her mother, who died recently, with whom she always fought only instead of loving her. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

sudden onset blindness since 2 hours (sensorimotor symptom)

she is not much concerned about this blindness (La belle indifference)

During history taking she was only found upset while talking about her mother, who died recently, with whom she always fought only instead of loving her (stress factor history)
Physical examination is normal

Suggestive of a diagnosis of conversion disorder , also known as functional neurological symptom disorder

questions.text:
A father, who has lost his daughter as the result of a traffic accident involving a drunk driver, organizes a local chapter of a national group
campaigning to stop the sale of liquor to minors and to legislate mandatory jail time for anyone convicted of drunk driving. He says “If I can’t have my girl back, at least I can make sure it doesn’t happen to some other father,” he says. The defense mechanism that most likely accounts for this behavior is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sublimation

The father gets gratification from the impulse to save his daughter by helping others.

questions.text: A boy recognizes that the amount of water remains the same when transferred from a tall narrow glass to a wide-mouthed glass. Which stage of Piaget’s developmental model is he likely to have attained? (**)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Concrete operational stage

The concept of conservation develops in the stage of concrete operations. The primary sign that a child is still in the preoperational stage is that he or she has not achieved the concept of conservation or reversibility. Conservation is the ability to recognize that objects possess different compatible properties and the alteration of one property (e.g. height) does not necessarily alter other properties (e.g. volume). Conservation occurs in various dimensions – conservation of volume, quantity, number, area, and weight.
 

 

Piaget’s stages of cognitive development include sensorimotor stage, which begins at birth and lasts up to 2 years. Object permanence and insight is gained in this stage. 

During the stage of preoperational thought (2–7 years), the child develops symbolic play and semiotic function. Children in this stage are egocentric. 

In addition to conservation and reversibility, the child also develops syllogistic reasoning in the concrete operational stage (7–11 years). 

Formal operational stage (11 to the end of adolescence), is characterized by the development of the capability of hypothetico-deductive reasoning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mature defence mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Isolation

Isolation is a neurotic defence mechanism. It is separating an idea from the emotion that accompanies it.
Mature defence mechanisms: They are psychologically healthy mechanisms. These include:
[SAHASA]
S- Sublimation
A- Altruism
H- Humour
A- Anticipation
S- Suppression
A- Asceitism

questions.text:
Which of these are causes of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
A. NPH
B. Hypothyroid
C. LBD
D. Vitamin B12 deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All except C
Causes of reversible dementia:
Depression
NPH
Hypothyroid

questions.text: Capgras syndrome can be associated with which of the  following condition? FMGE July 2023
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dementia with lewy body, commonly has CAPGRAS SYNDROME

It is 2nd most common cause of dementia in elderly
Fluctuating cognitive impairment
Parkinson like symptoms
Subcortical dementia
Has REM sleep behavioural disorder
Antipsychotics are contraindicated
Predominant visual hallucinations

questions.text: Dementia can be differentiated from pseudodementia by all of the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In some elderly patients with depression, marked difficulties with concentration and memory can present similar to dementia. 
Presence of previous history of depression; clearly observable depressed mood; biological symptoms of depression; voluntary complaints about memory failure (patients with dementia tend not to realize their own memory problems); indifference and ‘I don’t know’ answers when formally testing memory (while confabulation may be seen in dementia); and response to antidepressant medication (unusual in true dementia) are some clues to pseudodementia. 

In cognitive tests, visuospatial and executive functions can be impaired in dementia but such impairment is highly unlikely to be due to isolated depression. Neurological signs, including frontal release, points towards dementia.

questions.text: Rett's syndrome is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Macrocephaly (Ref : Kaplan synopsis of psychiatry, 11th edition, pg 1166)

In Rett’s syndrome, during the first 5 months after birth, infants have age-appropriate motor skills, normal head circumference, and normal growth. Social interactions show the expected reciprocal quality. 

At 6 months to 2 years of age, however, these children develop progressive encephalopathy with a number of characteristic features. 
The signs often include the loss of purposeful hand movements, which are replaced by stereotypic motions, such as hand-wringing; the loss of previously acquired speech; psychomotor retardation; and ataxia. 

Other stereotypical hand movements may occur, such as licking or biting the fingers and tapping or slapping. The head circumference growth decelerates and produces microcephaly. All language skills are lost, and both receptive and expressive communicative and social skills seem to plateau at developmental levels between 6 months and 1 year. Poor muscle coordination and an apraxic gait with an unsteady and stiff quality develop. All of these clinical features are diagnostic criteria for the disorder. Associated features include seizures in up to 75 percent of affected children and disorganized EEGs with some epileptiform discharges in almost all young children with Rett's disorder, even in the absence of clinical seizures. An additional associated feature is irregular respiration, with episodes of hyperventilation, apnea, and breath holding. The disorganized breathing occurs in most patients while they are awake; during sleep, the breathing usually normalizes. Many patients with Rett's disorder also have scoliosis. As the disorder progresses, muscle tone seems to change from an initial hypotonic condition to spasticity to rigidity.

choices.text: If a, b, c are correct
If a and c are correct
If b and d are correct
If all four (a, b, c, & d) are correct

Multiple Completion Type : AIIMS NEW PATTERN Clinical features of tourette’s syndrome?

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

TOURETTE’S SYNDROME

questions.text:
Consider the following statements (INICET NOV 23)

1-Contemplation - A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking but not sure

2 - Precontemplation - A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to the health

3- Maintenance phase- A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then

4- Action phase- A person with obesity says he cant do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Statement 1 and 3 are correct

questions.text: The opium withdrawal symptoms start with in hrs of last intake?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

12-24 hrs (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

"The onset of withdrawal symptoms occurs typically within 12-24 hours, peaks within 24-72 hours, and symptoms usually subside within 7-10 days of the last dose of opioid."

questions.text: Hemp insanity is related to which substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cannabis (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)

‘Hemp insanity’ or cannabis psychosis: Indian hemp insanity was first described by Dhunjibhoy in 1930. It was described as being similar to an acute schizophreniform disorder with disorientation and confusion, and with a good prognosis.

questions.text: In   an   alcoholic   patient,   which   of   the following causes “DELIRIUM TREMENS”? (AIIMS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acute infection (Ref : Kaplan)
“Alcohol withdrawal delirium is a medical emergency that can result in significant morbidity and mortality.  Untreated, DTs has a mortality rate of 20 percent, usually as a result of an intercurrent medical illness such as pneumonia, renal disease, hepatic insufficiency, or heart failure. The essential feature of the syndrome is delirium occurring within 1 week after a person stops drinking or reduces the intake of alcohol. In addition to the symptoms of delirium, the features of alcohol intoxication delirium include autonomic hyperactivity such as tachycardia, diaphoresis, fever, anxiety, insomnia, and hypertension; perceptual distortions, most frequently visual or tactile hallucinations; and fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from hyperexcitability to lethargy. About 5 percent of persons with alcohol-related disorders who are hospitalized have DTs. Because the syndrome usually develops on the third hospital day, a patient admitted for an unrelated condition may unexpectedly have an episode of delirium, the first sign of a previously undiagnosed alcohol-related disorder. Episodes of DTs usually begin in a patient’s 30s or 40s after 5 to 15 years of heavy drinking, typically of the binge type. Physical illness (e.g., hepatitis or pancreatitis) predisposes to the syndrome; a person in good physical health rarely has DTs during alcohol withdrawal.”
